case_data.name: EEOC v. PARMALAT BAKERY DIV. of NORTH AMERICA
case_data.plaintiff_description: Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, on behalf of one or more workers.
settlement_agreement: Court Approved Settlement or Consent Decree
case_data.summary:
In August 2003, the Philadelphia office of the EEOC brought this Title VII suit against Parmalat Bakery Division of Parmalat North America in the U.S. District Court for the District of New Jersey. The complaint alleged that the defendant discriminated against the claimant by subjecting her to a hostile work environment (because of her sex), retaliation for her complaint, and constructive discharge. The claimant intervened in the EEOC's suit. The case settled by entry of a consent decree in March 2004.

The consent decree required the defendant to refrain from discrimination and retaliation; pay the claimant $300,000 in damages; post notice; and provide Title VII training for all of its managers, supervisors, and employees.

documents.text:
Case 2:03-cv-04026-JCL-MF     Document 15      Filed 03/02/2004     Page 1 of 1
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT
DISTRICT OF NEW JERSEY
                                                            
EQUAL EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITY COMMISSION CIVIL 03-4026(JCL)
                                                  (CLOSED)
                 V.
                               
PARMALAT BAKERY DIVISION OF PARMALAT     O R D E R
NORTH AMERICA                         
It appearing that it has been reported to the Court that
the above-captioned matter has been settled,
It is on this 1st   day of March            2004,
ORDERED that this action be and is hereby dismissed, without
costs and without prejudice to the right, upon good cause shown 
within  60  days,  to reopen the action if the settlement is not 
consummated.
/s/ JOHN C. LIFLAND, U.S.D.J.

CONSENT DECREE 
This Consent Decree is entered into between the Plaintiff, Equal Employment Opportunity 
Commission (lithe Commission"), and the Defendant, Parmalat Bakery, DivisiOTl orPal111alat NOl1h 
America ("Defendant"). 
On August 26, 2003,  the Commission brought this action against Defendant under the 
provisions of Tille VIf or the Civil Rights Act of 1964, as amended, 42 IJS.C. ~2000e ct seq, 
("Title VII"), and Title 1 of the Civil Rights Act or 1991,42 U.S.c. 91981A, alleging a sexually 
hostile work environment, retaliation ,l1ul constructive discharge 011 behalf of Linda Castanza. 
This Decree is final and hinding between the parties signatory hereto as to all issues raised 
in the COl11mission's Complaint filed in Civil Action Number 03-4026. Tn resolution of'Civil.Action 
1 

Case 2:03-cv-04026-JCL-MF     Document 16      Filed 03/31/2004     Page 2 of 5
No. 03-4026, the parties hereby agree as follows: 
I.  Thi~ Decree is entered into in compromise to avoid the expense and inconvenience 
of litigation. It shall not constitute an adjudication or finding on the merits ofthe case and shall not 
be constnted as an admission of liability by Defendant. The Commission does not construe this 
Decree as a delemlination that the Commission is a prevailing party and the Commission tahs no 
position on whether Castanza is a prevailing party in this action. 
2.  The Commission is  the agency of the  United States governmcnt authorizcd  by 
Congress to irivestigate allegations of unlawful employment discrimination based upon sex, to bring 
civil actions based upon these allegations of up lawful practices, and to seek relieffor individuals 
alTec!ed by such practices. 
3.  The partics stipulatc that,p.ursuant to 28 l).S,c. ยง 1331, the United States District 
Court for New Jersey has jurisdiction over the subject  matter and  the parties in this case. 
4.  Defendant agre(;lS to comply fully with all of the provisions of Title VIl, including 
its anti-retaliation provisions. This means that Defendant wiJi 110t take action against any individual 
becaus;: s/be ;:x;:rcised any of his or her rights under Title VII, including filing a charge, providing 
tcstimony or assistance, participating in any manner in any Title VII investigation, proceeding or 
. 
. 
,," 
hearing, or opposing any practice that s/he believed in good faith to he unlawful under Title VII, 
5.  Defendan( agrees (0 pay  monetary relief ill the total amount of Three IIundred 
Thousand Dollars ($300,000.00) to Linda Castanza.  Defendant will issue a check to Ms. Cas(an~a 
within lourl\:en (14) days of the date a fully executed  Release  has  been  received by Defendant 
from Ms. Castanza. The check shall be sent, postage prepaid, to Ms. Linda Castanza, c/o Broach & 
Stulberg, Eleven Penn Plaza, Suite 915, New York, New York 1000 I. A copy of!he check shall be 
sent to Cynthia A. Locke, Trial Attorney, EEOC, Philadelphia District Office, The ]Jourse Building, 
2 

Case 2:03-cv-04026-JCL-MF     Document 16      Filed 03/31/2004     Page 3 of 5
Suite 400, 21 S. Fifth Street, Independence Mall Rast, Philadelphia, PA 19106. 
6.  Tn order to obtain the relief referenced in Paragraph No.5, Ms. Castanza shall  execute 
a Release provided by Defendant, and lorward that Release to the Defendant. 
7.  Within ten business days oflhe filing of this Consent Decree,  Defendant shall post 
the Notice attached to this Decree as Exhibit A at its Kearny, New Jersey racility, on the bulletin 
boards where notices are usually and customarily posted for the benefit of all employees. The Notice 
will remain posted ror a period of 120 days. Defendant shall replace said Notice with a legible copy, 
if the Notice is defaced, removed, or malTed in any way. Within len business days of the posting of 
the Notice, Defendant will send a copy ofthe l':Iotice, and an indication of the date and location of 
its posting, to the Commission. 
8.  Defendant agrees that a vendor approved by EEOC will conduct training on sexual 
.,,,' 
harassment and retaliation under Title VII for Defendant's managers, supervisors, and employees 
with supervisory authority at the Kearny, New Jersey facility within 120 days of the filing or this 
Decree.  Defendant agrees  io  nolily  the  Commission of the  date  or the  training,  and  provide 
inionnalion regarding the substantive content of' the training to the Commission at least five (5) 
working days prior to the training. 
9.  In the event of any dispute or question between the Commission and Defendant as to the 
interpretation 01' implementation of this Decree, the parties shall attempt to resolve such question 
informally within thirty (30) days. Ifthe parties are unable to resolve their diflt'l'cnccs, the issue shall 
be submitted to the Comt fOT /inal decision. 
10.  The palties request that the COllrt retain jurisdiction over this Decree ihr a period of 
onc year after its filing in order to enforce its proviSions, should this become necessary. 
11.  This Decree shall be med in the United States District Court, District of New Jersey, 
3 

Case 2:03-cv-04026-JCL-MF     Document 16      Filed 03/31/2004     Page 4 of 5
12.  This case shall be and hereby is dismissed with prejudice, subject to this Court'~ 
jurisdietion to enforce the provisions of this Consent Decree. 
13.  Each party to this Consent Decree shall bear their own costs and attorney's tees.

EXBllBIT A 
Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 ("Title VII"), 42 U.S.C. Section 2000e, et seq. 
as amended,  prohibits discrimination against employees and applicants for employment based 
upon their race, color, sex, religion or national origin.  Title VII further prohibits retaliation 
again;!t employees or applicants who avail themselves of their rights unde!' Title VII by engaging 
in prctected activities such as the filing of a charge of discrimination. 
The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (the "EEOC") is the federal agency 
that investigates charges of discrimination and, if necessary, brings lawsuits in federal district 
court to enforce Title VII. 
This notice is being posted pursuant to a Consent Decree entered between the EEOC and 
Parm.ilat in EEOC y, Panna1at Bakgy. Divisj(m of North Ameri~ Civil Action No. 03-4026 
(D. NJ). 
Pannalat fully supports and will comply with Title VII in all respects. Parmalat will not 
enga!:e in any employment practice which operates to deny equal employment opportunities in 
vio1alion of Title VI1.  Furthermore, in ac.cordance with Title VU, Parmalat will not take any 
actioll against any employee or applicant for employment becau~e he or she has exercised any 
right under Title vn, including the filing of a charge of discrimination. 
This Notice will remain posted at Parmalat's Kearny, New Jersey location for a period of 
120 cays and must not be defaced or removed. This Notice will be available for inspection by all 
empl,)yces. 
THIS NOTICE MUST NOT BE REMOVED 
FOR A PERIOD OF 120 DAYS 
Pannalat Bakery, Division ofParmalat North 
The Equal Employment Opportunity 
America

documents.title: EEOC Litigation Settlements - March 2004
documents.text:
EEOC LITIGATION SETTLEMENT REPORT - MARCH 2004 http://www.eeoc.gov/litigation/settlements/settlement03-04.html
EEOC v. Parmalat Bakery Div. of North Am.
No. 03-4026 (D.N.J. March 31, 2004)
The Philadelphia District Office brought this Title VII action, alleging sexual harassment, retaliation and
constructive discharge against defendant, a New Jersey division of an international company
headquartered in Italy that produces and distributes snacks, bread, pasta and similar products.
Charging party, a sales division manager and the only woman in an office of four male executives, was
subjected to unwelcome sexual advances, sexually explicit comments, the showing of a pornographic
video, and unwelcome touching by her supervisor and other male executives during her employment
at the New Jersey facility. Her supervisor asked her to attend sales meetings at his apartment, a
topless bar, and a swingers club, invitations which she refused, and required her to attend
work-related dinners at Hooters and a transvestite karaoke bar where the entertainment included lap
dances and strip tease contests. While charging party initially did not complain about the harassment
because she believed her supervisor and the human resources manager condoned it, she eventually
complained to her supervisor about a coworker slapping her on the buttocks. In response, her
supervisor told her if she reported the incident, he would fire her. CP complained anyway to the vice
president of sales and vice president of human resources, and her supervisor instructed her peers to
ostracize her. He also threatened to suspend her, and made derogatory comments about her
performance and gave her a low rating. Suffering from post-traumatic stress and depression, CP took
a leave of absence and never returned.
The case was resolved by a consent decree that requires defendant to pay a total of $300,000 to
charging party. In addition, the decree provides that defendant will not retaliate against individuals
who engage in protected activities, and will provide training on sexual harassment and retaliation by
an EEOC-approved vendor for its managers, supervisors, and employees at the New Jersey facility.
